Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Oxidative Reactivity of Pd and Ni Complexes Employing Paramagnetic Oxidation States
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award funded by the Chemical Synthesis and Catalysis Programs, Professor Liviu Mirica of the Department of Chemistry at Washington University in St. Louis will synthesize novel paramagnetic Pd(III) and Ni(III) complexes and investigate in detail their electronic properties and reactivity, with the long-term goal of developing catalytic transformations that involve these less common oxidation states. Of particular interest are Pd-mediated aerobic oxidative C-H functionalization reactions and detailed reactivity studies of organometallic Ni(III) complexes relevant to cross coupling reactions. These studies include a combination of synthetic organometallic and inorganic chemistry, catalysis, electrochemistry, and physical inorganic spectroscopy, and thus will provide the students interdisciplinary training and the opportunity to develop a broad range of scientific skills. In addition, these studies will be fully integrated with outreach activities that will expose students from underrepresented groups to chemistry through lectures and demonstrations at public schools from the St. Louis metro area.

Palladium and nickel complexes act as catalysts for a wide range of chemical reactions that are essential for the synthesis of commodity chemicals, fine chemicals, and bioactive compounds. The proposed research should lead to unique metal-mediated oxidative transformations relevant to organic synthesis that may impact how chemists put atoms together to build complex molecules more efficiently and economically.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of this grant we have synthesized uncommon high-valent organometallic Ni(III) and Ni(IV) complexes and have studied in detail their reactivity. This is of broad interest to the chemistry community given the large number of recent reports of Ni-catalyzed organic transformations that propose the involvement of such high-valent intermediates. For example, in 2016 we have reported the first isolated Ni(III)-dialkyl complex and have shown that this species is involved in stoichiometric and catalytic C-C bond formation reactions. This is important since organometallic Ni(III) intermediates with aryl and/or alkyl ligands are commonly proposed as the active intermediates in cross-coupling reactions, yet no such species have been isolated before our report. Interestingly, the rate of C-C bond formation from a Ni(III) center is enhanced in the presence of an oxidant, suggesting the involvement of transient Ni(IV) species and that both Ni(III) and Ni(IV) species could play an important role in a range of Ni-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions, especially those involving alkyl substrates.

This research project took advantage of our ability to judiciously design flexible multidentate ligands that can stabilize various coordination geometries and oxidation states and generate metal complexes that will exhibit both bioinorganic and organometallic reactivity profiles. Moreover, the use of a wide range of mechanistic and spectroscopic techniques has provided key insights into the reactivity of these systems in order to develop selective and efficient catalysts for aerobic C-H functionalization and C-C/C-heteroatom bond formation reactions. Finally, the performed studies have generated metal complexes with unique reactivity profiles and should lead to unique Ni-mediated oxidative transformations relevant to organic synthesis, which may impact how chemists put atoms together to build complex molecules more efficiently.

We have also been involved in outreach and broader impact efforts in order to expose students from an early age to chemistry in particular and sciences in general. Our group has participated again in the Science Gone Mad program, co-organized by our group and the student-run Campus Y Catalyst organization. This program included field trips to WashU, where middle school students visited several science labs, performed experiments, and interacted with college students and teachers and learned more about college and experience some of the college life. In addition, the PI has given many lectures at PUI's in order to encourage undergraduates to pursue advanced degrees in science in general and chemistry in particular, and we have established partnerships with faculty from these institutions in order provide research opportunities for their students. Finally, the performed studies have provided graduate students an interdisciplinary training and the opportunity to solve a scientific puzzle by employing various techniques, develop a broad range of scientific skills, as well as find the type of chemistry that is best fit for their future interests.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2018
Modified by: Liviu M Mirica
